metadata.title: Effect of diethyl ether and Al2O3 nano additives in diesel-biodiesel-ethanol blends: Performance, combustion and emission characteristics

sections.text:
biodiesel (40 %)-ethanol (20 %)) (denoted as BE). Comparative analysis was done for addition of Diethyl ether (DEE) and alumina nanoparticle (Al2O3) at various concentrations. The test fuels used are BE, BE with 25 ppm Al2O3 (denoted as BN-1), BE with 50 ppm Al2O3 (denoted as BN-2), BE with 5 % DEE (denoted as BE-1) and BE with 10 % DEE (denoted as BE-2). Experimental results indicate that, DEE addition in BE results in increased HC (Hydrocarbon), CO (Carbon monoxide), CO2 (Carbon dioxide) and BSFC (Brake specific fuel consumption) with lowered NOx (Oxides of nitrogen) and smoke emission. This is attributed to high latent heat evaporation of mixture and Low temperature combustion (LTC). Al2O3addition in BE resulted in increase in NOx and smoke with lowered HC, CO, CO2 and BSFC. This could be attributed to enhanced surface area to volume ratio of mixture during rapid combustion process, higher catalytic combustion and reduced evaporation. At higher engine loads, the peak pressure of BE-1 is highest and that of BE-2 is lowest. Peak heat release rate of BE is highest and BN-1 is lowest. BE blends with additives (Al2O3 and DEE) resulted in higher Particulate matter (PM) formation, however BN-1 blend showed lowered PM at engine loads of 75 % and 100 %. Overall, BE-1 and BN-1 reflects better engine performance, combustion and emission characteristics.
Keywords: Diesel-biodiesel-ethanol; Alumina nanoparticle; Diethyl ether (DEE); Engine performance; Emission ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The quest for potential alternative fuel for agriculture, industry, transportation and power sector is on a raising trend as there was noticeable depletion of fossil fuel reserves. In addition, global warming concerns and ozone layer depletion affected the atmosphere significantly due to conventional fossil fuel combustion, industrial and radioactive wastes [1]. Alcohols and its blends as an alternative fuel in internal combustion engines was a major research since 1970’s. The major drawback of alcohol blending with diesel blend is phase separation/ mixture stratification. For avoiding such issues, works were carried out with usage of emulsifier/solvents [2, 3] with ethanol-diesel blends. Ethanol-diesel blends and its physicochemical properties like density viscosity, surface tension, specific heat, cetane rating, etc., plays a vital role in influencing the atomization, ignition, injection along with combustion and emission properties [4]. With an idea of neglecting the emulsifier and bringing down the overall fuel cost, works were done using biodiesel as an emulsifier between the diesel-
ethanol blends such that the tri-fuel mixture pattern (dieselbiodiesel-alcohol) forms a stable mixture [5-11]. The choosing of ethanol/ methanol for the tri-fuel pattern is purely concerned with outcomes of emissions. With comparative analysis of BDE (Biodiesel-diesel-ethanol) and BDM (Biodieseldiesel-methanol) in CI (Compression ignition engines) by Yilmaz [7], it is observed that, BDM showed higher BSFC than BDE. With higher alcohol concentration in BDE and BDM, reduced NOx and increased HC, CO emissions were noticed. The author also concluded that, choosing ethanol in tri-fuel mixture reduced the NOx and choosing methanol resulted in reduced HC and CO emissions. In general, addition of metallic powder to a hydrocarbon fuel improves the combustion efficiency and flame stability.
Among various metallic powders, aluminium nano powder is considered to be suitable as it liberates hydrogen atoms at higher cylinder [12]. Improved combustion speed with addition of aluminium nano powder (0.5 %) to a rocket fuel further elucidates the performance of metallic particles at combustion [13]. Metal oxides addition in water/diesel emulsion fuel [14] activates the molecular bonding between the mixtures and produces chemical reaction. Arul et al. [15] investigated the effects of cerium oxide nanoparticle as an additive *Corresponding author. Tel.: +91 8939118102, Fax.: +91 44 2357606 E-mail address: harishvenuresearch@gmail.com † Recommended by Associate Editor Jeong Park © KSME & Springer 2017
for diesel-biodiesel-ethanol blends. They found out that the addition of ethanol in diesel increases the ignition delay and heat release rate while the addition of cerium decreases the ignition delay and heat release rate. Also, cerium oxide nanoparticle addition improved the rate of combustion and reduced the exhaust emissions significantly. They concluded that, metal oxides acts as an oxygen donor, thereby reducing the thermal NOx by absorption of O2 and supplies O2 for oxidation of CO emissions. Metal oxide nanoparticle can cause significant reduction in number weighted size reduction, reduced light-off temperature and higher oxidation rate. Effects of premixed fuel fraction of Diethyl ether (DEE) in a HCCI engine were investigated by Cincinar et al. [16]. DEE addition resulted in lowered diffusion combustion, improved NOx-soot trade off characteristics, and lowered EGT (Exhaust gas temperature) (by 23.8 %) with slightly increased HC and CO emissions. Qi et al. [17] investigated the effects of DEE and ethanol as additives to Biodiesel-diesel blends (BD) in a DI diesel engine. They concluded that the effect of DEE is reduced BSFC, smoke and CO whereas ethanol addition resulted in increased NOx and HC emissions with reduced smoke. Also, the combustion characteristics are improved for DEE blended BD blends in comparison with ethanol blended BD blends.
Imtenan et al. [18] investigated the impact of oxygenated additives such as ethanol, n-butanol and DEE to palm and jatropha biodiesel blends in a light duty diesel engine. Experimental results revealed that the use of DEE reduced NOx by 13 %, increased brake power and brake thermal efficiency by 4.10 % and 4.4 % at 2200 rpm engine speed. Use of ethanol as additive reduced CO emission by 40 %. Even though various techniques available for emission reduction, usage of a fuel catalyst is preferred since it improves the fuel efficiency with simultaneous harmful pollutant reduction, especially NOx and PM (Particular matter). Addition of a metal additive/ metal-organic additive reduces the ignition delay, acts as a surfactant and as an anti-oxidant, during the combustion of metal oxides, hydroxyl radicals (OH-) were generated which enhances the soot oxidation by reacting with carbon atoms, thereby lowering the fuel oxidation temperature [19].
Aqueous aluminium nanofluid combustion in diesel fuel was studied by Kao et al. [20]. It is observed that, aqueous nanofluid not only reduces fuel consumption, but also reduces the exhaust emissions significantly. Tewari et al. [21] used Multi wall carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) as additives for biodiesel blends and results were found to increase the Brake thermal efficiency (BTE) with slightly higher HC and CO emissions. Works with ferrous picrate additives were carried out by Zhu et al. [22]. Ferrous picrate addition resulted in reduced ignition delay and combustion duration significantly, thereby causing higher in-cylinder pressure and faster heat release rate.
Gan et al. [23] performed a comparative study using micro and nano sized aluminium particle suspension in combustion and emission characteristics. They found that, suspension of
nano sized particles can remain stable for much longer time than micron suspensions due to higher surface area to volume ratio and higher level of particle surface interaction which could overcome the density differences. They also observed the distinctive stages of combustion of fuel droplets. Stabilized n-decane/nano-Al droplets exhibited 5 distinctive stages (preheating, classical combustion, micro explosion, surfactant flame and droplet flame), while stabilized n-decane/micron-Al exhibited only three distinctive stages (preheating, classical combustion and microexplosion) with similar mass-based particle and surfactant concentration. Usage of ferric chloride (FeCl3) as fuel catalyst for waste cooking palm biodiesel were performed by Anand et al. [24] and found to improve the BTE by 6.3 % with lower NOx and higher CO2 emissions. NOxsmoke trade-off characteristics were affected by the subjection of Alumina nanoparticle in water diesel emulsion fuels [25]. It is found that, application of alumina nanoparticle in emulsion fuels favors the oxidation reaction thereby simultaneously reducing the NOx and smoke emissions.
Metal oxides acts as an oxidation catalyst if used as an additive in base fuel and can produce chemical reaction [26]. There were reports of metal oxides improving the rate of combustion by photo electro catalytic effect as a result of H2 generation when used in water based emulsion fuels [27]. Aluminium oxide nanopowder addition to fossil fuel improves the combustion stability and combustion efficiency when used in rocket fuels [28] due to high catalytic activity of aluminium oxide nanopowder [29, 30]. University of Chicago [31] reported that H2O and OH- when reacted with aluminium powder can generate H2 and promote fuel combustion.
Bazyn et al. [32] analyzed the combustion behavior of 80nm sized aluminium particle in O2-N2 mixture using shock tube apparatus. Experiments were conducted at pressure of 4- 32 atm and temperatures of 1200-2100 K. The burning time and flame temperatures were measured using temporal variations in emitted light intensity and pyrometry. Results indicated that, for nanoparticle the flame temperatures were lower as that of ambient gas temperature at 4 atm pressure. Also, the burning time varied as an exponential function of gas temperature.
Combustion of alumina nanoparticle can be basically divided into two phases [32, 33]. Initially, there occurs an detached vapor phase flame around the particle along with symmetric/steady combustion where AlO and AlO2 were forced as sub oxides. The second stage follows the un symmetric/unsteady combustion, where the spinning of particles with ejection of sub-oxides speculative at particle surface. Further detailed combustion characteristics of aluminium particles can be found in Refs. [32, 33].
Initially it was surmised that, the burning rate is controlled by mass diffusion across the oxide layer or by chemical kinetics [32]. However, works of Park et al. [34] indicated that the oxidation rate was primarily controlled by chemical kinetics rather than mass diffusion which are not observed earlier in case of Bazyn et al. [32].
Dilip et al. [35] illustrated three possible burning scenarios for nano Al2O3 particles as shown in Fig. 1. They briefed about the step by step progress in combustion of Al2O3 by fracture of oxide layer, core-shell and particle surface. They also concluded that with melting of core and oxide shell of Al2O3, the diffusion process speeds up as a result of improved oxidation rate.
In the present work, experiments were conducted to study the performance, emissions and combustion characteristics of Biodiesel (40 %)-Diesel (40 %)-Ethanol (20 %) denoted by BE, Biodiesel (40 %)-Diesel (40 %)-Ethanol (20 %) with 25 ppm alumina nanoparticle denoted by BN-1, Biodiesel (40 %)-Diesel (40 %)-Ethanol (20 %) with 50 ppm alumina nanoparticle denoted by BN-2, Biodiesel (40 %)-Diesel (40 %)-Ethanol (20 %) with 5 % Diethyl ether denoted by BE1 and Biodiesel (40 %)-Diesel (40 %)-Ethanol (20 %) with 10 % Diethyl ether denoted by BE-2.

sections.heading: 2.1 Precursors and experimental fuels
sections.text:
Al2O3 nanoparticle were synthesized using sol-gel method and characterized for grain size using Scanning electron microscope (SEM) (Make: VEGA-3-TESCAN) (Fig. 2(a)). TEM morphology of Al2O3 nanoparticle were done using JEM-3010 ultrahigh resolution analytical electron microscope and the result is illustrated in Fig. 2(b). TEM morphology of Al2O3 nanoparticle confined to the crystalline nature with minimal agglomeration and aggregate formation. The average grain structure was about 20 nm. XRD (X-Ray diffraction) of synthesized γ-Al2O3 nanoparticle is shown in Fig. 3(a). The diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 with planes (110), (200), (211), (310), (411), (521) and (541) confirms to the crystalline structure of synthesized nanoparticle. Strong peaks were observed in plane of (211) from which the grain size is calculated using Debye-Scherer’s method, D = k*λ / (β*cosθ) Where, D- average grain size of the nanoparticle, k- Shape factor (0.89), λX-Ray wavelength of Al2O3 (1.54Å), β-Full width at half maximum (FWHM) (5.128 * 10-3), 2θ- Bragg angle (37.46o), θ = 18.73o and hence, “D” is calculated to be 28.22 nm. EDS (Energy dispersive X-Ray spectroscopy) spectrum is analyzed by INCA energy 250 microanalysis system and the results
were shown in Fig. 3(b). EDS results confirms to the presence of aluminium and O2 elements in the composition. Also, there were no impure atoms in report.
Properties of synthesized Al2O3 nanoparticle were listed in Table 1. Jatropha biodiesel was prepared by transesterifying the raw jatropha oil, whose initial viscosity is higher (7.4 cSt). Ethanol used for experimentation is industrial grade anhydrous ethanol (99.97 % pure). Diesel fuel used for preparation of fuel blends were procured from commercial petroleum reserve. BE blend is prepared at volume basis at Biodiesel (40 %)-Diesel (40 %)-Ethanol (20 %). For BE-1, 95 % of the BE mixture is blended with 5 % DEE and for BE-2, 90 % of the BE mixture is blended with 10 % DEE. BN-1 and BN-2 were prepared by blending a fraction of 25 ppm Al2O3 and 50 ppm Al2O3 with BE mixture. All the fuel blends were initially stirred magnetically for 30 minutes each followed by ultrasonication for 15 minutes, the main property of blending
stocks were given in Table 4.

sections.heading: 2.2 Error and uncertainty analysis
sections.text:
During experimental measurements and calculation of various performance parameters, errors are significant. Several factors like device selection, calibration, relative condition, environment, reading, observation and test planning influences the occurrence of errors and uncertainties. In order to prove the accuracy of obtained results, uncertainty analysis is needed. Uncertainty of various instruments along with its range and resolution were given in Table 2. The overall uncertainty of the current experiment is calculated as below.
Overall uncertainty of the experiment = Square root of{(uncertainty of TFC)2 +(uncertainty of load)2+ (uncertainty of brake thermal efficiency)2 + (uncertainty of CO)2 + (uncertainty of unburned hydrocarbon)2 + (uncertainty of NOx)2 + (uncertainty of smoke number)2 + (uncertainty of exhaust gas temperature)2 +(uncertainty of pressure pickup)2} = square root of {(1)2 + (0.2)2 + (1)2+ (0.2)2+ (0.2)2 + (0.2)2+ (1)2+ (0.15)2+ (1)2 } = ± 2.045 %.

sections.heading: 2.3 Experimental setup and procedure
sections.text:
Experiments were conducted on a single cylinder four stroke diesel engine (Kirloskar: TV1) since various agricultural applications and portable generators in India uses this engine. The test engine specifications were listed in Table 3. The engine was coupled to eddy current dynamometer with electrical resistance followed by a dynamometer controller. The concentrations of exhaust emissions (HC, CO2, CO, NOx and O2) were measured with the help of five gas analyzer (Model: QRO-402 make: QROTECH Co Ltd., Korea). Smoke was measured by a part-flow smoke opacimeter (AVL 437C). A high precision flow meter was installed to measure the fuel flow every 20 second.
A piezoelectric transducer (Model: 7063-A Make: Kistler) was installed for monitoring cylinder pressure which is con-
nected with charge amplifier (Kistler instruments AG, Switzerland). Schematic of the experimental setup is shown in Fig. 4.

sections.heading: 3.1 Ignition delay (ID)
sections.text: Ignition delay (ID) is the duration (in terms of crank angle degree) between SOI (Start of injection) and SOC (Start of combustion). Ignition delay depends on various factors like physical/chemical properties of fuel, cylinder temperature and pressure, cetane number, etc. Fig. 5 shows the variation of ID with respect to crank angle. With increasing engine load ID reduces due to higher cylinder temperature inside the cylinder chamber [36]. It can be observed that BE and BE-1 exhibits similar ID while BE-2 has highest ID of 28 degree at 25 % load). With increasing DEE concentration, ID is increased due to lowered formation of ignition centres in the cylinder. These are in good agreement with earlier findings [37]. In case of BN blends, BN-1 exhibits higher ID than BN-2 throughout the engine load condition However, the delay period of BE remains lower than both the BE blends.

sections.heading: 3.2 Combustion duration (CD)
sections.text:
Combustion duration (CD) indicates he progressive burning in the cycle. It is defined as the time interval (in terms of crank angle degree) between SOC (Start of combustion) and EOC
(End of combustion) [34]. SOC is taken at the angle where sudden HRR occurs, while EOC is the angle at which 90 % combustion occurs. From Fig. 6, it can be seen that with increasing engine load, CD increases due to more fuel fraction taking part in combustion. With DEE addition (BE-1), the CD reduces tremendously due to improved combustion rate (DEE acts as an ignition enhancer), When DEE concentration increases (BE-2), the CD is lowered by 3.3 %, 13.6 %, 13.5 % and 4.4 % at engine loads of 25 %, 50 %, 75 % and 100 %, respectively.
This could be attributed to latent heat and volatility properties of DEE which forms various ignition centres within the combustion chamber which reduces the overall burn duration. In case of nano additives, BN-1 has lowered CD than BE throughout the load while CD of BN-2 fluctuated between the loads. At engine loads of 0 % and 25 %, the CD of BN-2 were higher by 16.66 % and 8.51 % in comparison with BE, while at 25 %, 75 % and 100 % loads the CD of BN-2 is marginally lower than BE. This may be due to higher mixture density with 50 ppm nano additives which affects the easier evaporation at lower loads while at higher loads; the increased cylinder temperature facilitates the evaporation followed by lowered CD.

sections.heading: 3.3 Cylinder pressure variation
sections.text:
In diesel engines, the peak in-cylinder pressure and Rate of pressure rise (ROPR) depends mainly on the mass of burnt fuel during the Premixed combustion phase (PCP). PCP is defined as the duration of combustion of fuel which has mixed with air to within flammability limit during the delay period. Cylinder pressure speculates the ability of the fuel to mix spontaneously with air and to start burning. High peak pressure and ROPR mainly corresponds to excess fuel burnt in premixed combustion phase. Fig. 6 illustrates the variation of cylinder pressure at 100 % engine load condition operating with BE, BE-1, BE-2, BN-1 and BN-2. Their corresponding peak pressures are 65.4 bar, 66.384 bar, 58.03 bar, 64.597 bar and 62.21 bar, respectively. BE-1 exhibits highest cylinder
pressure of 66.384 bar followed by BE. The main reason attributed to this is reduced ignition delay (Fig. 5). Higher ignition delay especially for BN-2 could be attributed to denser fuel mixture where the possibility of atomization is minimized. Earlier fuel combustion is caused by higher latent heat vaporization of DEE mixture. However, higher DEE concentration in BE-2 affects the strong premixed combustion phase and thereby causing lower peak pressure, especially for BE-2.
Even though combustion starts at almost similar crank angle for BE-1 and BN-1, the presence of DEE and ethanol in BE-1 improves the latent heat properties of the mixture along with low viscosity and higher volatility, resulting in more fuel air mixture formation during ignition delay followed by strong premixed combustion phase and higher peak pressure, especially for BE-1.

sections.heading: 3.4 Heat release variation
sections.text:
The Heat release rate (HRR) at each crank angle for various test fuels were calculated using the correlation derived from first law of thermodynamics by Eq. (1):
n lw dQ γ dV 1 dP= P + V +Q dθ γ-1 dθ γ-1 dθ æ ö æ ö ç ÷ ç ÷ è ø è ø & (1)
where ndQ dθ is the net heat release rate (J/oCA), P is the instantaneous cylinder pressure (N/m2), V is the instantaneous cylinder volume (m3), θ is crank angle (degree) and γ is the ratio of specific heats Cp/Cv (kJ/kgK). γ depends on temperature and influences the intensity of ndQ dθ and lwQ .& lwQ& is the
blow by losses which are evaluated by Rakopoulas [38]. The gross heat release rate can be calculated by Eq. (2):
g n lwdQ dQ dQ= + dθ dθ dθ
(2)
where lwdQ dθ is the amount of heat transfer rate to the combus-
tion chamber walls [39]. Fig. 6 shows the variation of Heat release rate (HRR) of engine running at 100 % full load with test fuels BE, BN-1, BN-2, BE-1 and BE-2. Their respective heat release rates are 76.497 J/oCA, 63.824 J/oCA, 68.267 J/oCA, 70.66 J/oCA and 66.80 J/oCA, respectively. BE exhibits highest heat release rate of 76.497 J/oCA followed by BE-1 and rest of the blends. Initially, vaporization of fuel mixture results in negative heat release due to accumulation of fuel during the delay period. As the combustion begins, HRR becomes positive. The main reason for BE to exhibit highest HRR could be attributed to the presence of pure ethanol in BE without any additives (DEE and Al2O3). The presence of pure ethanol enhances better mixing with air, reduced ignition delay and earlier start of combustion resulting in highest HRR compared to rest of the blends.
The HRR of BE attains higher heat release than BE-2, the peak HRR of BE-2 occurs exactly near the TDC. This can be explained on the basis of latent heat properties, cetane number and ignition delay of the fuel mixture. Despite the higher cetane number of DEE, the higher concentrations of DEE prolonged the delay period [40]. Hence, with BE-2 higher volatile and low latent heat properties of DEE diminishes, leading to longer ignition delay followed by lowered HRR and peak HRR occurring away from TDC.

sections.heading: 3.5 Lambda (Relative air fuel ratio) variation
sections.text: From Fig. 9, it is evident that BE-1 exhibits lowest lambda (relative air fuel ratio). Lambda decreases as engine load increases as an indication of lean-mixture engine operation. The addition of nanoparticle with BDE blend helps the engine to operate leaner than other blends since nanoparticle acts as an oxygen buffer at higher temperatures. DEE addition in BE results in richer engine operation due to high latent heat of evaporation of DEE which is also evident from increased BSFC of BE-1 (Fig. 10).

sections.heading: 3.6 Brake specific fuel consumption
sections.text:
Fig. 10 clearly shows the variation of brake specific fuel consumption with brake power for all the test fuels. Highest BSFC was observed for BE-1 followed by BE, BE-2, BN-1

and BN-2. DEE addition in BE results in reduced blend viscosity and causes improvement in shape of fuel spray and atomization. Thus, this fine fuel droplet mixes spontaneously with air and thereby improves combustion [41]. Combustion of BE-2 is superior to that of BE-1 in aspect of molecular level penetration of fuel droplets resulting in 18.2 % reduction of BSFC compared to neat BE. The reason for BN-1 and BN-2 to exhibit lowest BSFC is that, owing to catalytic combustion activity of Al2O3 nanoparticle throughout the engine load condition.
As the concentration of nanoparticle increases, BSFC reduces, i.e. for a given engine load condition, amount of fuel consumed by the engine to maintain constant speed is lowest in comparison with other blends.

sections.heading: 3.7 Oxides of nitrogen
sections.text:
Fig. 11 shows the concentration of oxides of nitrogen (NOx) from the exhaust gas of BE, BE-1, BE-2, BN-1 and BN-2 fuel blends with brake power. NOx emissions are sensitive to oxygen content, AFT (Adiabatic flame temperature) and fuel spray characteristics. In general, a fuel ensuring complete combustion will give higher cylinder temperature followed by more NOx formation [17].
During diffusion combustion stage, higher in cylinder temperature and pressure causes NOx as a result of thermal
mechanisms. NOx is also formed as a resultant of thermal mechanisms during the diffusion combustion stage which causes higher in-cylinder temperature and pressure. Throughout the engine load conditions, DEE and Al2O3 nanoparticle addition reduced the NOx invariably. Drastic reduction was observed with BE-2 (1048 ppm at 100 % load). DEE addition not only reduces NOx emissions, but reduces the smoke emissions too thereby modifying the NOx-smoke trade off characteristics. As the DEE % increases, peak heat release rate occurs during the premixed and diffusion phases of combustion. NOx is also affected by the change in angle of occurrence of main combustion with respect to TDC (Top dead centre), while the other blends exhibits peak heat release (Fig. 8) earlier to angle of occurrence. This could be the sole reason for BE-2 to exhibit lowest NOx formation, but not as significant as BE-2. BN-1 has 6.2 % lowered NOx, while BN-2 resulted in 28.2 % NOx reduction with respect to BE. The main reason for such occurrence could be due to, denser the fuel mixture is, lesser the light off temperature is, thus due to insufficient temperature required to burn down all the nanoparticle, thereby resulting in lowered NOx emissions, especially for BN blends.

sections.heading: 3.8 Carbon monoxide variation
sections.text:
Variation of CO emissions for all the test fuels with respect to brake power at 1500 rpm is illustrated in Fig. 12. CO emissions from IC engines are controlled by the fuel/air equivalence ratio. Diesel fuel operates well on the lean side of the stoichiometric and hence formation of CO is low enough to be considered unimportant [42]. But, in the combustion of alternative fuels where the fuel oxygen is predominant, CO formation is typical and found to deviate widely from equilibrium, especially at expansion stroke. The effect of alcohol and ignition improver changes the fuel spray characteristics, oxygen content, oxidation rate, cylinder temperatures and ignition center formation which influence the formation of CO. Also, CO formation depends upon the physical-chemical properties of the fuel.
Higher CO is observed for BE-1 and BE-2 throughout the engine load conditions. Since smoke levels of BE-1 and BE-2
are relatively lower, incomplete combustion cannot be attributed to CO elevation. The possible reason could be the promotion of LTC with DEE addition, even at higher engine loads. Addition of oxygenate blends promotes LTC and this lower temperature may not be sufficient for further oxidation of CO molecules trapped in the engine cylinder thereby resulting in higher CO emissions. With Al2O3 nanoparticle addition, lower load CO reduction and higher load CO increase is observed. The possible reason could be due to nanofuel mixture operating well at lean mixture at lower loads. As the engine load increases, BN blends lowers the rate of combustion, which is evident from higher smoke opacity (Fig. 15), where the incylinder temperature is not sufficient to burn down all the BN mixture (i.e., lower oxidation rate for Al2O3) at higher loads resulting in higher CO formation.
This above phenomenon of oxidation of BN blends can also be explained on the basis of stages of oxidation in nano aluminium particles stated by Dilip et al. [35] as shown in Fig. 13. At lower loads, the CO emission of BN-1 and BN-2 were in par with BE, while at higher loads the CO emissions were higher. This could be attributed to insufficient time for oxidation of BN blends while BE-1 and BE-2 facilitates the oxidation with fuel bound O2 atoms which results in conversion of CO to CO2 throughout the engine load condition. At higher
loads, more fuel enters the cylinder and when more fuel with lesser energy content takes part in combustion, incomplete combustion occur which results in higher CO emission.

sections.heading: 3.9 Hydrocarbon variation
sections.text:
Fig. 14 illustrates the variation of HC with respect to brake power for various test fuels. BE-1 and BE-2 exhibits higher HC throughout the engine load, in comparison with BE. Higher latent heat of evaporation of DEE mixture promotes LTC during the combustion, thereby resulting in more fuel accumulation during the premixed combustion phase which is predominant in engine combustion chamber walls.
The temperature near the cylinder walls during the mixture formation influences the HC formation especially at cylinder boundary [16]. This causes more unburned hydrocarbon formation for BE-1 and BE-2. Also, with DEE addition, the late escape into the cylinder of excess fuel trapped at nozzle sac is evaporated easily and slipped into the cylinder, lately during the expansion stroke, causing higher HC for BE-2. BN-1 and BN-2 exhibits lower HC emissions throughout the engine load, except at 100 % load condition, where the catalytic combustion activity of Al2O3 nanoparticle is not well recognized as earlier as lower and part loads. Combustion of nanoparticle is temperature dependant. The splitting of oxides from metal oxides, in general requires much cylinder temperature and higher reaction time [35]. At 100 % load, even though the cylinder temperature is comparatively higher, the combustion duration is lower (Fig. 6) in comparison with BE-1, since more fuel is injected into the cylinder and all the fuel entered into the chamber does not take part in combustion thereby causing higher HC emissions with respect to BE, especially at 100 % engine load.

sections.heading: 3.9.1 Smoke opacity variation
sections.text:
From Fig. 15 it is observed that, BE-1 and BE-2 exhibits lowered smoke throughout the engine load condition. Lowest smoke is observed for BE-2 (7 % at 100 % load). This could be attributed to higher volatility, enriched O2 supply and improved evaporation with DEE addition. Also, higher ignition
delay (Fig. 5) which causes more fuel accumulation during the premixed combustion phase, resulting in more complete combustion followed by lowered smoke. When considering BN blends, reduced smoke at 25 % and 50 % load while increased smoke at 75 % and 100 % loads were observed. The main reason is, at lower and part engine loads, the optimum engine parameters co-exist for promoting the catalytic powercombustion of Al2O3 nanoparticle. With increase in load, more fuel is injected into the combustion chamber. With increase in addition of nanofuel mixture in combustion chamber, the physicchemical properties are greatly modified especially the density, viscosity, molecular structure and atomization. Denser the mixture is, poorer the atomization of fuel droplet is. Thus, the state of combustion is almost incomplete, thereby liberating more smoke emissions.

sections.heading: 3.9.2 Carbon dioxide variation
sections.text:
Carbon dioxide (CO2) which is a chief inhibitor of greenhouse gases forms an important role in combustion of oxygenated blends. Fig. 16 depicts the variation of carbon dioxide with brake power. For all the engine loads (except 75 % engine load) CO2 emissions were slightly reduced for nano blended BDE blends. At 75 % engine loads, all the CO2 emissions are almost similar for all the blends. BE-1 exhibits slightly increased CO2 emissions than the rest of the blends which indicates that the DEE blended fuels enhance the combustion. CO2 and water vapor (H2O) are the products of com-
plete combustion. It is to be noted that, DEE blended fuels enhances combustion at lower engine temperature itself (Low temperature combustion) and also it is evident for reduced smoke opacity (Fig. 15). Considering nano additives, at lower loads, BN-1 and BN-2 were lower. As the engine load increases, CO2 emissions for BN blends increases, indicating improved oxidation with addition of Al2O3 nanoparticle. Higher the rate of combustion is, higher the formation of CO2 is. Thus, 2.4 % increase in CO2 for BN-2 and 6.82 % increase in CO2 for BN2 is noticeable at 100 % engine loads.

sections.heading: 3.9.3 Exhaust gas temperature variation
sections.text: From Fig. 17, we infer that the Exhaust gas temperatures (EGT) for all the blends were similar except BE-1. At lower engine loads, the EGT of BE-1 is less (147 oC) due to the presence of DEE promoting Low temperature combustion (LTC). But, at higher engine loads it exhibits highest temperature of 429 oC. The main reason for such an improvement in EGT is due to higher in cylinder temperature at high loads (also evident from high heat release rate), where all the oxygen content in BE-1 vaporizes due to better atomization and volatility promoting higher combustion rate.

sections.heading: 3.9.4 Particulate matter (PM) variation
sections.text:
Particulate matter (PM) is generated as a result of insufficient O2 content in fuel rich zones, especially during heterogeneous combustion [43]. In general, in comparison with diesel, oxygenate blends lowers the PM emissions due to reduced aromatics, C/H ratio and the presence of readily available O2, which improves the combustion rate followed by lower PM formation. From Fig. 18, we can infer that BN-2 has highest PM in comparison with other blends. At lower loads, PM formation is less owing to less fuel fraction burnt, whereas PM formation increases with increasing load due to excess fuel accumulation resulting in higher burn duration.
Throughout the engine load condition, PM emission of BN2 and BE-1 were almost same while the PM formation of BE, BN-1 and BN-2 seemed to be load dependant. At engine loads till 50 %, the presence of additives (Al2O3 and DEE) has raised the PM emission while at 75 % and 100 % loads, in comparison with BE, BN-1 reduces while BE-2 increases. This could be attributed to the catalytic activity of nanoparticle
making it significance at higher loads causing better O2 utilization followed by lowered PM emissions.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
This paper experimentally presents the effect of DEE and Alumina nanoparticle addition in diesel-biodiesel-ethanol blends (BE) in a single cylinder diesel engine. Nanoparticle addition in BE blend resulted in reduced BSFC, NOx, HC, CO2 with increased CO and smoke emissions. Whereas, DEE addition in BE blend showed reduced smoke, NOx, Lambda with increased with increased BSFC, CO, HC and CO2 emissions. BE-1, BE-2 and BN-2 blend showed higher PM formation throughout the load in comparison with BE, however BN1 showed lower PM at 75 % and 100 % loads. The combustion characteristics of BE-1 and BE-2 were better compared to BN blends due to higher oxygen content and high volatility of the blend. As a result, BE-1 and BN-1 were considered as promising blends in reducing harmful emissions with increased performance in diesel engines without engine modification.
Nomenclature------------------------------------------------------------------------
BE : Biodiesel (40 %)-diesel (40 %)-ethanol (20 %) DEE : Diethyl ether Al2O3 : Alumina nanoparticle BN-1 : BE with 25 ppm Al2O3 BN-2 : BE with 50 ppm Al2O3 BE-1 : BE with 5 % DEE BE-2 : BE with 10 % DEE BSFC : Brake specific fuel consumption CO2 : Carbon dioxide NOx : Nitrogen oxide EDS : Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy SEM : Scanning electron microscope TEM : Transmission electron microscope TDC : Top dead centre ROPR : Rate of pressure rise PCP : Premixed combustion phase HRR : Heat release rate
DI : Direct injection HC : Hydrocarbon CO : Carbon monoxide PM : Particulate matter EGT : Exhaust gas temperature LTC : Low temperature combustion ID : Ignition delay CD : Combustion duration SOI : Start of injection SOC : Start of combustion

metadata.abstractText: The present experimental work is focused on improving the performance and emission characteristics of biofuel blend (diesel (40 %)biodiesel (40 %)-ethanol (20 %)) (denoted as BE). Comparative analysis was done for addition of Diethyl ether (DEE) and alumina nanoparticle (Al2O3) at various concentrations. The test fuels used are BE, BE with 25 ppm Al2O3 (denoted as BN-1), BE with 50 ppm Al2O3 (denoted as BN-2), BE with 5 % DEE (denoted as BE-1) and BE with 10 % DEE (denoted as BE-2). Experimental results indicate that, DEE addition in BE results in increased HC (Hydrocarbon), CO (Carbon monoxide), CO2 (Carbon dioxide) and BSFC (Brake specific fuel consumption) with lowered NOx (Oxides of nitrogen) and smoke emission. This is attributed to high latent heat evaporation of mixture and Low temperature combustion (LTC). Al2O3addition in BE resulted in increase in NOx and smoke with lowered HC, CO, CO2 and BSFC. This could be attributed to enhanced surface area to volume ratio of mixture during rapid combustion process, higher catalytic combustion and reduced evaporation. At higher engine loads, the peak pressure of BE-1 is highest and that of BE-2 is lowest. Peak heat release rate of BE is highest and BN-1 is lowest. BE blends with additives (Al2O3 and DEE) resulted in higher Particulate matter (PM) formation, however BN-1 blend showed lowered PM at engine loads of 75 % and 100 %. Overall, BE-1 and BN-1 reflects better engine performance, combustion and emission characteristics.
